reasoning: The critique targets an important supporting pillar of the essay’s optimism: that partial convergence plus trade/compromise (including via ‘hybrid goods’) can still yield mostly-great futures despite deep value divergence. If hybridization opportunities largely disappear under high optimization, that would weaken the trade-based route, but it wouldn’t fully collapse the essay (which also discusses splitting resources across regions, partial satisfaction, institutions, and many blockers). The critique’s core point—a tension between “optimization causes value-forks” and “compromise finds robust hybrids”—is plausible and largely correct as a pressure on the hybrid-goods mechanism. However, the essay itself already anticipates much of this: it explicitly notes that gains from compromise may be small for linear/non-discounting views, raises “narcissism of small differences,” and treats trade optimism as conditional and threatened by extortion. So the critique is more a highlighting of an internal tension/needed justification than a decisive refutation, hence moderate centrality but limited strength. It’s clearly stated, focused, and contains little fluff.
title: High optimization erodes the hybrid goods that moral trade requires
